data.title: USA Rare Earth: A $4.1B Bet On Breaking China's Grip -- But Execution Has To Catch Up
data.description:
USA Rare Earth (USAR) has seen more than its fair share of volatility since listing in March 2025. The stock has more than tripled to current levels from the March lows of ~$6, despite giving back most of its gains after spikes over $40 in October 2025, and another in January, which tested highs around ~$32. The company has been propelled by a string of government funding announcements and a separate $1.5B private placement. However, its fundamental story is lacking and based on speculation.

Pre-revenue with an enlarging cost base

Apart from a short trading history (<1 year), USAR remains a company with no revenue. During the first three quarters of 2025, no sales were recorded, while adjusted operating expenses have climbed from $8.8M in 2Q25 to $8.9M in 3Q25. This excludes the $3.2M in stock-based compensation, M&A costs, and severance pay. The management expects 4Q25 adjusted OPEX to reach $13M-$15M, reflecting an accelerated hiring spree and commissioning activity at its Stillwater plant.

If we steer back to GAAP, we have to work with a noisy set of data. The net loss in 3Q25 was in fact $156.7M, or -$1.64 per share. This was mainly due to a $142M non-cash fair value adjustment on warrant and earn-out liabilities. In 2Q25, GAAP net loss was $142.5M, or -$1.54/share. The net loss is persistent with growing costs.

The company finished the third quarter with $257.6M cash in hand and no significant debt. Operating cash flow burn was $21.1M during the first three quarters of 2025. Capex spend has been steadily increasing—$3M/$3.2M/$7.1M in 1Q/2Q/3Q of FY25. This was primarily for improving plant and equipment.

Recapitalization keeps it going

In January 2026, USAR closed a $1.5B PIPE deal, and issued 69.8M shares at $21.50, with Inflection Point as the anchor investor. Later in the same month, the company announced a non-binding letter of intent with the U.S. Department of Commerce's CHIPS program, which led to up to $1.6B in funding that consists of $277M in proposed grants and $1.3B in senior secured loans. In return, 16.1M shares and ~17.6M warrants were issued to the DoC.

The obvious drawback is dilution. As of the end of January, there were ~217.9M in outstanding shares, with up to 76.3M shares listed for resale, or about 35% of the total float. The share dilution effect is a strong overhang on the stock, as evidenced by the 12% drop in the share price on the PIPE closing day.

Reducing reliance on China's rare earth

The company's Stillwater plant in Oklahoma is a magnet manufacturing plant expected to be in commission in 1Q26. The initial production rate is 600 metric tons/annum (tpa), before scaling to 1200 tpa, and finally to a full capacity of 4,800 tpa.

USAR acquired the UK's Less Common Metals (LCM) in November 2025 for $100M in cash and 6.54M in shares. This acquisition will bring in 1,500 tpa of NdFeB strip cast capacity, expanding to 2,000 tpa in 2026.

Fueled by geopolitical fears

After China imposed export controls on seven heavy rare earth elements in April 2025, it further expanded them in October 2025 and subsequently suspended the latter until November 2026. China's RE magnet exports fell by ~75% in the two months following the initial controls, and as a result, neodymium prices have surged roughly 124% since January 2025, to $214.80/kg in February 2026.

Below is a neodymium price chart in CNY (¥).

USA Rare Earth's heavy critical minerals project is essential to restoring U.S. critical mineral independence."

Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick (source)

Not only is the funding pipeline credible, but it has garnered bipartisan support as it is a national urgency.

But let's pause and look at fundamentals

The gap between the company's aspirational targets (pp. 10) and execution is still pretty wide. By 2030, the management expects to hit $2.6B in revenue, $1.2B in EBITDA, and $900M in FCF. So far, market analysts have only put FY26E revenue at ~$51M, increasing to $281M in FY27E and to $858M in FY28E. EBITDA is not expected to turn positive until FY28E when it will reach $62M.

As of 3Q25, the Stillwater plant has yet to produce its first magnet, let alone being able to manufacture at scale. Any further status update on its timeline to begin commissioning in 1Q26 would be welcome.

Its Round Top deposit in West Texas, which has heavy rare earths, gallium, and other critical minerals waiting to be extracted, still has to pass its pre-feasibility study, aimed to be done by 3Q26. Thus, we do not expect any revenue contribution here until at least 2028.

The economic viability of domestic RE producers rests strangely on the actions of China.

As China's export control on REs has sparked urgency on domestic suppliers, the spigot is still very much under the control of China. A relaxation of its supply can cause rare earth prices to crash, as with any commodity. China has shown that it will use its dominance in rare earths as a negotiation tactic in trade talks.

A competitive landscape

MP Materials (MP) is a larger competitor valued at $10.4B, has ~$276M in revenue in the past twelve months. It operates the sole active rare earth mine in North America. It also has close ties with the Department of War. However, USAR has an edge in heavy rare earths, which MP doesn't produce at scale. Despite this, MP still has multiple years of a head start and is expected to turn a profit as early as FY26E, according to market estimates.

Valuation and Verdict

At current levels, USAR trades at 36x FY26E earnings, which is high for an industrial miner, but possibly justifiable since rare earths are a sensitive, politicized commodity. Looking further out at $858M in FY28E revenue, the market estimates imply an FY28E P/S of 2.1x. We sense that this valuation is still on the expensive side—market estimates ($62M EBITDA on $858M revenue) imply a 29x FY28E EV/EBITDA multiple, whereas industrial miners tend to trade below 10x EV/EBITDA even during bull markets.

Also, dilution is a big overhang for the stock. There are still $280M+ of warrants to be exercised on the balance sheet. The SEC filings contain risk factors that explicitly mention "significant dilution associated with the expected U.S. Government investment and PIPE transaction." Management has indicated it will need additional capital to fund the full four-line buildout at Stillwater (at least $250M in capex plus $50M-$100M in working capital) and the Round Top development.

We are not bearish on domestic rare earth suppliers due to geopolitical tailwinds, significant government support and funding, and ultimately the strategic importance of such minerals to defense, EVs, wind, and semiconductors. That said, current valuations are off-putting, and we believe more production milestones need to be reached for us to consider an investment that targets profitability in FY28+.

We rate USAR as a HOLD. We look forward to its next earnings release on March 19 to learn more about its progress at Stillwater.

data.title: SPYM: S&P 500 Monthly Dashboard For March
data.description:
About SPYM

This article offers a top-down analysis of the S&P 500 Index based on valuation, quality, and momentum metrics in GICS sectors. It may also help analyze funds tracking the index, such as State Street® SPDR® Portfolio S&P 500® ETF (SPYM), previously known as SPDR Portfolio S&P 500 ETF (SPLG). SPYM is less popular than SPDR S&P 500 ETF Trust (SPY), but it is a very large and liquid ETF, with $107.6 billion in assets under management and an average daily volume of $923 million. Additionally, SPYM has a cheaper expense ratio compared to SPY (0.02% versus 0.09%) and a lower share price, offering more flexibility for small investors. In summary, SPYM is best suited for long-term investors, while traders prefer SPY’s huge liquidity (averaging $54 billion per day) and ultra-low spreads and slippage.

Shortcut

The next two paragraphs in italics describe the dashboard methodology. They are necessary for new readers to understand the metrics. If you are used to this series or if you are short of time, you can skip them and go to the charts.

Base Metrics

I calculate the median value of five fundamental ratios in every sector: Earnings Yield ("EY"), Sales Yield ("SY"), Free Cash Flow Yield ("FY"), Return on Equity ("ROE"), Gross Margin ("GM"). All are calculated on trailing 12 months. For all these ratios, higher is better, and negative is bad. EY, SY and FY are medians of the inverse of Price/Earnings, Price/Sales and Price/Free Cash Flow. They are better for statistical studies than price-to-something ratios, which are unusable when the "something" is close to zero or negative (for example, companies with negative earnings). I also calculate two momentum metrics for each group: the median monthly return (RetM) and the median annual return (RetY).

I prefer medians rather than averages because a median splits a set into a good half and a bad half. Capital-weighted averages are skewed by extreme values and the largest companies. As a consequence, these metrics are designed for stock-picking rather than index investing.

Value and Quality Scores

Historical baselines are calculated as the averages over a look-back period of 11 years for all metrics. They are noted respectively EYh, SYh, FYh, ROEh, GMh. For example, the value of EYh for technology in the table below is the 11-year average of the median Earnings Yield of S&P 500 tech companies.

The Value Score "VS" is the average difference in % between the three valuation ratios (EY, SY, FY) and their baselines (EYh, SYh, FYh). In the same way, the Quality Score "QS" is the average difference between the two quality ratios (ROE, GM) and their baselines (ROEh, GMh).

VS may be interpreted as the percentage of undervaluation or overvaluation relative to the baseline (positive is good, negative is bad). This interpretation must be taken with caution: the baseline is an arbitrary reference, not a supposed fair value. The formula assumes that the three valuation metrics are of equal importance, except in energy and utilities, where the Free Cash Flow Yield is ignored to avoid some inconsistencies. VS and QS are capped between -100 and +100 when the calculation goes beyond these values.

Interpretation

A hypothetical S&P 500 median company is overvalued by 13% relative to historical averages since 2015. Its quality score is close to the historical baseline. Median valuation ratios calculated as the inverse of yields are as follows:

  • Price/Earnings: 27.47

  • Price/Free Cash Flow: 42.55

The energy sector has the highest value and quality scores since February 2022. Real estate is undervalued by 13% based on 11-year averages and is close to its quality baseline. Healthcare is almost at its historical baseline regarding both value and quality. Consumer staples, communication, and financials are overvalued by less than 10%. Overvaluation may be offset by a good quality score for financials. Technology, consumer discretionary, and utilities are overvalued by 17% to 19%, with a good quality score for consumer discretionary and utilities. Industrials and materials are overvalued by 27% and 32%, respectively. The latter is the least compelling sector from a fundamental point of view, with both the lowest value and quality scores.

The S&P 500 performance was significantly skewed by mega-caps in 2025, but the bias reversed recently to give quite balanced 12-month returns in the cap-weighted index (17% measured on SPYM), the equal-weight index (15.7% measured on RSP) and the index median (13.3% reported in the table above).

The table above is not only useful to calculate value and quality scores. It may also help spot companies with attractive value relative to their peers. For example, the EY column tells us that a large consumer staples company with an earnings yield above 0.0364 (or price/earnings below 27.47) is in the better half of the sector regarding this metric. data.title: The Marcus Corporation: Still Cheap After The Q4 Run-Up
data.description:
Marcus Corporation (MCS) reported earnings yesterday, and, as usual, Wall Street underestimated them (the third straight double beat).

What’s unusual this time isn’t that.

It’s that I actually went to the movies for the first time in seven years!

Well, if you follow my articles here on Seeking Alpha and read my write-up about another movie theater operator, Cineplex (CGX:CA), you should know that the last time I left home to see a movie was to watch Tarantino's latest film ('Once Upon a Time... in Hollywood').

I ended up watching 'The Housemaid' because my wife wanted to—I can already hear the jokes—and, other than overpriced popcorn, it was a good experience.

But it seems I wasn't the only one who ended up going to the movies this quarter.

As I told you, Marcus is in a sweet spot right now.

Both the Theatres and Hotels divisions have clear catalysts ahead (a pipeline full of family films for FY 2026 and the end of major renovations on key assets like the Hilton Milwaukee), monetization possibilities given the high concentration of owned properties, and a clean balance sheet.

This gives them optionality.

If heavy Capex is behind them, the Net LT Debt/EBITDA is very close to pre-pandemic levels at 1.4x, and there are leveraged competitors out there paying rent, they not only have the capacity to increase shareholder returns from dividends and buybacks but also continue to be a consolidator in the Midwest.

And that's exactly what I highlighted in my last article here.

Speaking of past articles, we're up ~10% since I started covering this company last September, well ahead of the S&P, which delivered just over 6% in the same stretch.

Of course, not all stocks of this type are booming.

Only two companies in the sector beat the S&P during the same period, and Marcus is one of them.

Cineplex, for example, has already fallen almost 10% in the same period.

To tell you the truth, that doesn't scare me. Cineplex has always been a story of divestment and deleveraging, something quite different from Marcus, as I showed you.

But despite the good results, I told you I was targeting a range of $20 to $23.50 in one or two years. So, we still have an upside of ~20 to 25% until then, which, added to the mid-digit shareholder yield I was projecting, gives us a fairly large margin of safety.

So, how's the thesis going?

Theatres: Normalization in Sight?

Although I, and a few other folks, have recently returned to the cinema, the narrative that many have tried to sell—that there will be a return to pre-pandemic numbers this year—is a lie.

If we add up the domestic box office for the entire year, we arrive at something slightly above $8.6 billion (only 1% above 2024 but almost 24% below 2019).

You could even argue that 2019 isn't such a comparable year, since many major releases came out, like Avengers: Endgame and The Lion King, but if you look back, in almost every pre-pandemic year the domestic box office exceeded $10 billion.

Besides not having normalized yet, the box office also hasn't reached the $9 billion projected by some analysts.

If you ask me, I think more was expected from some films with old superhero formulas like Captain America and Superman.

Animated films like 'A Minecraft Movie' and 'Lilo & Stitch' together grossed almost 10% of the total box office, which corroborates the thesis that family films have been much more profitable.

As I told you in my last two articles on Marcus, FY 2026 will be full of these family films like Zootopia 2 (which was released at the end of November and has already grossed $86.3 million, something like $928,000 per day), Toy Story 5, Super Mario Galaxy, and others.

All are sequels, of course. Even so, all should surpass $300 million in domestic box office (something that only six films managed to surpass last year).

Based on my estimates (considering Avengers: Doomsday will only be released in December), I think they could surpass that $9 billion estimate to something closer to $9.5 billion, with cheaper films (like The Housemaid and Wuthering Heights) boosting Gen Z and Millennial viewership.

But what about FY 2027?

Many say this year will be even better, with strong family titles like Frozen 3, Shrek 5 (that one I'll definitely want to see), and Minions 3.

Could this be the catalyst to push domestic box office numbers above $10 billion? I wouldn't venture to say, but there's a chance.

At Marcus, they achieved sales of $123.8 million in Q4 FY 2025, an increase of approximately 2.1% compared to the same period last year.

Beyond the one-off effect of the release of the film 'Song Sung Blue' (a very important film for the Milwaukee community in particular), Marcus has been able to see revenue growth through pricing.

If you look at the KPIs for the quarter, visitation fell 5.7% and was fully offset by a 12.7% increase in the average ticket price. Along with that, F&B per capita also jumped 7.2%.

Overall, they outperformed the national average by a good chunk of 760 bp.

Notice that this isn't the traditional expansion (the kind we saw even before the pandemic) of organic growth via volume, nor the previous low-price strategies of afternoon matinees. This is a premiumization strategy, and, given the elasticity of demand, it's working quite well.

If we consider that small jump in the year's box office and Marcus achieving some gains in pricing and cross-selling on family films, I imagine that instead of Theatres revenue growing at a low-single-digit rate as it did in FY 2025, it will increase to a mid-single-digit rate (something between 4 and 6%), taking them to $481.2 to $490.4 million.

The big question would be the margins.

With that premium push, they lifted the operating margin in the division from 4.9% to 6.3%. If that trend holds, mid-to-high-single-digit margins don't seem out of reach.

Answering the question I posed at the beginning of this section, if it happens, the normalization of box office revenue would occur in early 2027, with Marcus gaining market share while the industry continues to compete on price.

How Paramount Helped Theatre Operators

A piece of good news for theater operators that came out in the media today (February 27th, the day I'm writing this article) was the long-awaited Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD) deal with Paramount (PSKY).

And, to be honest, I didn't follow the intricacies of it. That's not exactly my area of ​​expertise.

But since I cover Marcus and other operators in this industry, Paramount buying Warner Bros. instead of Netflix (NFLX) saved them a lot of headaches.

To better understand this, we have to go back to David Ellison's statements during the bidding war.

He explicitly said:

  1. There will be a guaranteed minimum window of 45 days before releases go to streaming (more or less what it was in the post-pandemic period, when they reduced it from ~80 to 90 days);
  2. For major box office hits (I imagine films grossing over $300 million domestically), the idea is that the window should be 60 to 90 days;
  3. Paramount produces approximately 30 films annually for theatrical release.

Looking at it bluntly, if they actually follow through on these promises, of course—this would extend Paramount's average window of ~30 days, which is more than a week shorter than the industry average.

This all seems like a win for the establishment and, consequently, for Marcus.

There's no doubt that Netflix would try its best to push very short windows, further shortening the theatrical lifespan of each film.

It's fair to wonder if Paramount can maintain that volume of releases every year, like what happened with Disney (DIS) and Fox post-merger, but I think that's the lesser of two evils.

Hotels: Smart Allocation and What to Expect in 2026

Hotels are also holding up well, especially assets that have just come out of renovations, like the Hilton Milwaukee.

If you've read my write-ups on casinos like Monarch (MCRI) and Boyd Gaming (BYD), you'll know that the operators outperforming the national average are those that are constantly renovating their assets. One of the few local assets that hadn't been renovated, The Orleans, hampered the entire segment.

Take the Strip as an example. Operators that aren't upscale are seeing a significant drop in ADR and, ultimately, RevPAR. But this is happening elsewhere too, like in the South (Houston is a good example) and even in the Midwest, where Marcus has most of its assets.

According to data they revealed in the earnings call, in the U.S. RevPAR increased by only 0.8% (ADR-driven, of course), and in the Midwest, Marcus's competing hotels fell by 2% in FY 2025 as a whole.

Looking at the numbers they pulled in the last quarter, you can see they outperformed the national average by a large chunk.

ADR increased 5.6% (driven by renovations and premiumization of certain assets), and occupancy fell only 1.2% to 60.2%.

Marcus aimed and hit the 'k-shaped economy' at a very opportune time.

RevPAR grew 3.5%, about 550 bp higher than competitors in the Midwest.

You can also see the full-year effects of the renovations.

With rooms closed part of the year, Hotels revenue grew only 2.6% in the full FY 2025, with the adjusted EBITDA margin remaining virtually flat year-over-year.

Okay, but if they premiumized their room offering, why did margins shrink?

That's simple. Some rooms remained closed during the renovation period, as well as certain areas like the convention center and part of the lobby. Since fixed costs remained stable, it's understandable that they would be less diluted while assets are under renovation.

For the entire FY 2026, management expects RevPAR growth in the low-single-digits, more or less stable with Q4 FY 2025 (likely with some pressure on occupancy and ADR increasing). But the difference here is that bookings for this year are ~3% higher than FY 2025.

If I had to make a definitive prediction here, I'd say revenue would continue to grow in the low-to-mid single digits ($304 to $312.9 million) and margins would be slightly fatter compared to last year.

Unlike other hotel chains, the World Cup won't be a huge boost here.

Only Kansas City was chosen to host games, and since Marcus hasn't had properties there since 2015 (it sold the Phillips Hotel to focus on other markets), we probably won't see a very strong increase in bookings.

Good Old Cash Generation

In summary, my midpoint revenue projections for FY 2026 are approximately $800 million, closely matching the consensus of $796.5 million that Wall Street is targeting.

Since they've been surprised every quarter recently, I'd say I'll stick with my projection.

Premiumization efforts should push the EBITDA margin to ~13% (it's been hovering at 12.8% for the last two years), which would give us a full-year EBITDA of $104 million.

Using the same 85% conversion rate I used in the last analysis, we could project an OCF of $88.4 million. That time we needed to project Capex, but now we know it should be between $50 and $55 million.

This slightly reduces our previous FCF projection of $40 to $45 million to $33.4 to $38.4 million.

Even so, if we project dividends of $0.32 per share annually (a return of $9.8 million counting on the 30.7 million shares outstanding), they would be covered at ~3.6x the midpoint of the FCF.

If they use another $10 million to repurchase shares at ~$20 per share (being a little more conservative here), they would repurchase and retire 500,000 shares (buyback yield of just over 1.6%).

We are still left with a low-to-mid-single-digit shareholder yield. But since I believe they will soon increase dividends back to what they were before the pandemic, I'm aiming for a mid-single-digit yield very soon.

Still Cheap?

Even though I think my previous price target of $20 to $23.50 is quite current, I believe we could take a look at the P/CF since these numbers are right in front of us.

Assuming the buybacks do reduce the outstanding shares to 30.2 million and the OCF comes in at $88.4 million (OCF per share of $2.92), Marcus's 5-year average multiple indicates that they usually trade at ~8.2x that.

If you look at the pre-pandemic period and imagine a scenario of normalization ahead, the price target is only slightly above my projections at ~$23.90 per share.

I will reiterate my 'Buy' rating on Marcus, eyeing this minimum 20% upside and a low-to-mid-single-digit shareholder yield.

Unless we head into a recession, the combination of a strong FY 2026–FY 2027 film slate and ongoing hotel premiumization makes this investment case look less risky from here. I also support the M&A thesis in the Midwest given the low leverage of the balance sheet.
